title: In the sentence ,'It is raining', what does it refer to? - Quora

response.answer_text: “It” is a pronoun. Therefore, it must have and does have an antecedent. The antecedent is, necessarily, the noun form of the verb, in this sentence. Therefore, “it” (in this case) stands for rain. Hence, “The rain is raining.” Think about it. What else can rain, other than rain? Let’s look at a different example so that you understand the logic. “It’s raining fish.” So, what’s raining fish? UNLESS you have an antecedent OTHER than “rain”, the sentence is that, “The rain is raining fish.” That does sound odd. But the fact that a sentence sounds odd does NOT mean it is grammatically wrong. A pronoun ALWAYS has an antecedent, and it is NEVER random. Let’s look at a couple of ways that I have used “it” in my explanation, here. “But the fact that a sentence sounds odd does NOT mean it is grammatically wrong.” What is the antecedent of “it” here? Clearly, it is “a sentence”. Hence, “But the fact that a sentence sounds odd does NOT mean a sentence is grammatically wrong.” “A pronoun ALWAYS has an antecedent, and it is NEVER random.” Here, “it” stands for “antecedent”. Hence, “A pronoun ALWAYS has an antecedent, and an antecedent is NEVER random.”

There is no “it”, either in English “It’s raining” or in Spanish llueve. English speakers can say “It is raining” instead of “Rain is falling”. (BTW, in Japanese it’s ame ga furimasu, “rain falls/is falling”.) One of the main purposes of language is to communicate information about the world, but the accidents of grammar don’t tell you anything about the world. English needs a subject for a sentence, and nobody would say “I am raining” or “Fred is raining” etc., so the form English uses is some unspecified generic “it”. “It’s cold”. “It’s humid out here.” “It’s raining.” All of those can be expressed without seeming to claim some unspecified “it” exists: “The ambient temperature is far below the optimal temperature for humans.” “The dew point exceeds 70 degrees Fahrenheit.” “Rain is failing.” You should read up on a fellow named Meinong. He’s known for a more specific version of what you’re asking about—the notion that since there are true propositions that refer to nonexistent things (e.g. “The square circle is not in Des Moines, Iowa”), in some sense there is a square circle, but it just doesn’t exist. Um, OK… (I suspect that Bertrand Russell had much the same reaction; he wrote a paper, “On Denoting”, setting out his theory of descriptions. See also one of the early chapters of Principia Mathematica—ah, there we go, chapter 14.)
